column3: I have been trying to get a hold of a friend to help me with a project for over a week, but he won't return my calls or texts. And I think He is avoiding me
column4: I have been feeling really frustrated and worried because I've been trying to reach out to my friend for over a week now. I need their help with a project, but they haven't been returning my calls or texts. It's making me think that maybe they're avoiding me.
column5: It's possible that my friend is just really busy right now. They could be going through a personal situation, such as a family emergency or health issue that I'm unaware of. It's also possible that my messages have somehow been lost or overlooked in a backlog of messages. The project we're working on may be stressing them out and they need some space to work things out. Alternatively, they might not feel capable of helping with the project and are unsure of how to convey that. It may not be about me at all, but rather about them and their current circumstances.
column6: It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and worried about not hearing back from your friend. However, it's important to separate your thought that they might be avoiding you from the situation itself. It's possible that your friend is busy or going through a difficult time, which could be why they haven't been able to respond to you yet. Try not to jump to conclusions or assume the worst-case scenario. Instead, focus on the present moment and what you can control. You can try reaching out to your friend again and expressing your concern for their well-being. If they don't respond, try not to take it personally and focus on other support systems you have in your life. Remember, it's okay to feel upset, but try not to let it consume you.
column7: It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and worried about not being able to reach your friend. However, it's important to consider other possibilities beyond the assumption that they're avoiding you. Maybe they're busy with their own personal or professional commitments, or maybe they're just not checking their messages as frequently as you would like. Instead of jumping to conclusions, could you try sending them a gentle reminder or a new message expressing your need for their help? This way, you can approach the situation with a more open and non-judgmental mindset. Additionally, you could try reaching out to them in different ways, such as sending an email or giving them a call at a different time. By exploring other possibilities, you may be able to find a solution that works for both of you.
column8: Thank you for taking the time to brainstorm and explore these possibilities with me. It's important to recognize that your friend may be going through a difficult time, and their lack of response could be due to a variety of reasons. It's possible that they are indeed busy with personal issues, or that their messages have been lost or overlooked. Additionally, it's important to consider that they may not feel capable of helping with the project at this time, and that's okay. It's important to prioritize their well-being and communicate with them in a non-judgmental and supportive manner. I encourage you to reach out to them again and express your understanding and support. Remember, it's okay to be patient and understanding, and to prioritize their well-being over the project.

column3: I have depression and anxiety. The past 3 weeks have been especially tough depression wise, due to some out of our control stressors. spent a lot of time in bed while my kids were in school, just doing the bare minimum.  Meanwhile, my very supportive husband has been picking up my slack. I feel as though I nearly contribute to the household chores as much as I should, though I thank him constantly for his work.  Any words of wisdom or encouragement? And I think I feel like a bad wife and mom
column4: I have been feeling really down lately and it's been a struggle to even get out of bed. My depression and anxiety have been really overwhelming, especially in the past few weeks when there have been some stressors that I couldn't control. My husband has been so supportive and has been taking care of everything while I've been struggling, but I can't help but feel like I haven't been pulling my weight. I keep thanking him, but deep down, I feel like a bad wife and mom. Are there any words of wisdom or encouragement you can offer me?
column5: I'm suffering from mental health issues, such as depression and anxiety; several unforeseen incidents recently have aggravated my situation. For the last few weeks, I've had to rely heavily on my undeniably supportive husband, who's stepped in to fulfill our household responsibilities, as I've been somewhat incapacitated and spending lots of time in bed during school hours. My contribution in terms of home chores has been minimal, which I acknowledge and I constantly express gratitude to my husband for his help. I seem to struggle with feelings of guilt and inadequacy related to my perceived roles as a wife and mother. What can you suggest?
column6: Of course, I'm here to help. It's completely normal to feel overwhelmed and struggling with depression and anxiety, especially when there are stressors that are beyond your control. It's important to remember that you are not alone in this and that it's okay to feel overwhelmed. It's important to separate the situation from your thought and recognize that you are not a bad wife or mom just because you are struggling with your mental health. You are doing the best you can, and that's something to be proud of. It's okay to ask for help and support from your husband and other loved ones, and it's important to prioritize your own mental health and well-being. Remember, taking care of yourself is not a sign of weakness, but a sign of strength. Keep talking to your husband and other loved ones about how you are feeling, and don't hesitate to seek professional help if you need it. You are not alone in this, and there are many resources available to help you manage your mental health.
column7: Of course, I'm here to help. It's completely understandable to feel overwhelmed and struggling with negative thoughts, especially when there are stressors that are beyond your control. It's important to remember that you are not alone in this, and that it's okay to feel overwhelmed. Instead of beating yourself up over not being able to control everything, try to focus on what you can control, like taking care of yourself and seeking support from your husband and loved ones. It's okay to ask for help, and it's important to prioritize your mental health during this time. Remember, you are a good wife and mom, and you are doing the best you can in a difficult situation. Try to practice self-compassion and self-care, and remind yourself that you are strong and capable of getting through this.
column8:
Of course, I'm here to help. It takes a lot of courage to acknowledge and share your struggles with depression and anxiety, and I want you to know that you're not alone in this. It's completely understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and guilty about not being able to contribute as much as you'd like to your household responsibilities, especially when there have been stressors that you couldn't control.
Firstly, please know that your husband's support and care for you is invaluable, and it's okay to accept and appreciate it. It's important to recognize that you don't have to carry the burden of your mental health struggles alone, and that it's okay to lean on your loved ones for help. In fact, research has shown that social support from partners and family members can play a crucial role in managing mental health issues.
Secondly, it's important to practice self-compassion and self-care. It's okay to take time for yourself, to prioritize your own well-being, and to focus on your own healing. Remember that taking care of yourself is not a sign of weakness, but rather a sign of strength and resilience.
Lastly, consider seeking professional help, such as therapy or counseling, which can provide you with additional support and guidance in managing your mental health. A mental health professional can help you develop coping strategies, challenge negative thought patterns, and work through any underlying issues that may be contributing to your depression and anxiety.
Remember, you are not alone in this, and there are many resources available to help you. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you need further support.

column3: I hurt my families feelings by canceling the trip they had planned to come to see me. And I think I should have made time for them.
column4: I feel really guilty about canceling the trip my family had planned to come see me. I know they were really looking forward to it and I can't help but think that I should have made time for them.
column5: Although I canceled the trip and possibly hurt my family's feelings, I believe I made the decision considering my own well-being or important obligations that couldn't be postponed. In retrospect, not every decision we make is perfect or liked by everyone. Hence, different variables could have led to different decisions. I can choose to explain to them sincerely my situation and reasons for canceling the trip which may lead to them understanding and respecting my decision. Alternatively, I could plan another trip or meeting when I am better able to accommodate their visit. This can be seen as a learning experience to coordinate better plans for future visits.
column6: It's understandable that you feel guilty about canceling the trip your family had planned to come see you. However, it's important to recognize that you have your own needs and limitations that cannot be ignored. It's okay to prioritize your own well-being and make decisions that align with your values and goals, even if it means disappointing others. Instead of beating yourself up over this decision, try to focus on the things that you can control and find ways to make it up to your family in other ways. Remember, self-care is not selfish, it's essential for maintaining your own mental health and well-being.
column7: It's understandable that you feel guilty about canceling the trip, but try to reframe your thinking by focusing on the positive aspects of the situation. Instead of dwelling on what could have been, consider the benefits of having more time to yourself. You could use this time to relax, recharge, and focus on your own well-being. You could also use this time to plan a future trip or activity that you can enjoy with your family, when the time is right. By shifting your focus to the present and the future, you can break free from the guilt and find a more positive perspective.
column8:
Dear [Patient's Name],
I can see that you are struggling with feelings of guilt and regret regarding your decision to cancel the trip your family had planned to visit you. It takes a lot of courage to acknowledge and confront these emotions, and I commend you for doing so. By brainstorming and recognizing the different perspectives involved, you have taken an important step towards finding a resolution.
It's important to remember that we cannot always control how others feel or react to our decisions, but we can control how we communicate and handle the situation. By being honest and sincere with your family about your reasons for canceling the trip, you may be able to alleviate their disappointment and find a way to move forward together. Alternatively, planning another trip or meeting when you are better able to accommodate their visit can be a thoughtful gesture of goodwill and a chance to reconnect in the future.
Remember, it's okay to make mistakes and have to make difficult decisions. It's how we learn and grow from these experiences that matters. Keep in mind that you are not alone in this, and I am here to support you every step of the way.

column3: I hurt my family members by telling them to postpone their long-planned trip to visit me because I was too busy And I think I am selfish
column4: I feel really guilty and selfish for telling my family members to postpone their trip to visit me. They had planned it for a long time, but I was just too busy to spend time with them. I know I hurt them and I can't help but feel like a terrible person because of it.
column5: I requested my family to reschedule their trip to see me due to my workload. While I initially felt guilty and selfish for doing so, I could alternatively view this situation from a different perspective. Maybe I was demonstrating responsibility and prioritizing my professional commitments, which also contributes to my family's well-being in the long run. Or, my decision gave my family flexibility, giving them an opportunity to rearrange their journey to a more convenient time. In fact, I was ensuring that I could give them my full attention during their visit, making their trip more meaningful.
column6: It's understandable that you feel guilty and selfish for postponing your family's visit, but it's important to remember that your priorities and needs are also important. It's okay to set boundaries and prioritize your own well-being, even if it means disappointing others. It's important to communicate your feelings and needs in a clear and respectful manner, rather than internalizing the guilt and shame. Remember that you can't control how others feel, but you can control how you respond to the situation. Try to focus on finding a solution that works for everyone involved, rather than beating yourself up over the situation.
column7: It's understandable that you feel guilty and selfish for postponing your family's visit, but try to reframe your thinking by recognizing that you are not a terrible person for prioritizing your own needs. It's okay to set boundaries and prioritize your own well-being, especially when it comes to spending time with loved ones. Instead of beating yourself up over this decision, try to focus on finding a solution that works for everyone involved. Perhaps you could reschedule the visit for a later date when you are feeling more rested and able to fully enjoy their company. Remember, taking care of yourself is not selfish, it's essential for maintaining healthy relationships in the long run.
column8: Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It takes a lot of courage to confront and reframe our negative thoughts, and I commend you for doing so. By recognizing that your decision to postpone your family's visit was not selfish, but rather a demonstration of responsibility and prioritization, you are taking a positive step towards reframing your guilt. It's important to remember that prioritizing your work and personal commitments does not make you a terrible person, but rather a responsible and considerate individual. Your decision gave your family the flexibility to rearrange their visit, and ultimately, you will be able to give them your full attention when they do come to see you. Keep acknowledging and challenging these negative thoughts, and know that you are not alone in this process. Remember, you are doing your best, and that is something to be proud of.

column3: I invited a co-worker out and they turn me down And I think They will never want to go out with me
column4: I invited a co-worker out and they turned me down, and now I'm thinking that they will never want to go out with me. It's making me feel really rejected and embarrassed.
column5: Perhaps my co-worker had a prior engagement or is facing some personal issue that prevented them from accepting my invitation. There's also a possibility that they are not comfortable mingling with colleagues outside of work or they might be overloaded with work. Maybe they just weren't in the mood for going out at that particular instance. It could have less to do with me and more with their own circumstances. There will be other opportunities to invite them again, and their response might be different next time.
column6: It's understandable to feel rejected and embarrassed when someone turns down an invitation, especially when it's from a co-worker. However, it's important to remember that one person's decision not to go out with you doesn't define your worth or their interest in you. It's possible that they simply had other commitments or preferences that didn't align with going out with you at this time. Try not to take their rejection personally and instead focus on the many other people in your life who may be interested in spending time with you. Remember, rejection is a normal part of life and doesn't define your worth or identity.
column7: It's understandable to feel rejected and embarrassed when someone turns down an invitation, especially when it's from a co-worker. However, it's important to remember that one person's decision not to go out with you doesn't define your worth or their interest in you. There are many possible reasons why they may have declined, such as their schedule, personal preferences, or simply not feeling comfortable socializing with someone from work. Instead of jumping to conclusions, try to focus on the positive aspects of the situation. You could try asking them if there's another time that works for them, or simply move on and find other opportunities to socialize with people you enjoy spending time with. Remember, rejection is a normal part of life and doesn't define your worth or your social value.

column6: It's important to recognize that you are not your thoughts, and that they don't necessarily reflect your true feelings or values. column3: I just feel unmotivated And I think I just can't get moving
column4: I just feel so unmotivated lately, and I can't seem to get myself moving. It's like there's a constant weight dragging me down and I just don't have the energy or motivation to do anything.
column5: Although I'm feeling unmotivated and stuck at the moment, it's possible that this feeling is temporary. Perhaps I'm just experiencing a rut or going through a stressful period that's causing this lack of motivation. It's also possible that there are underlying issues contributing to this feeling, such as physical health problems, that I haven't addressed yet. Maybe I could try finding a new hobby or some form of physical activity to rekindle my motivation. It could also be beneficial to seek support from friends or family, or even speak with a professional about these feelings. It's also okay to accept that everyone has periods of being unmotivated, and it doesn't mean I'll never move forward again.
column6: It's understandable to feel unmotivated at times, and it can be challenging to separate that feeling from the situation itself. However, it's important to recognize that your motivation levels can fluctuate and are not necessarily a reflection of your worth or abilities. Instead of attaching to the thought of feeling unmotivated, try to observe it as a passing thought without judgment. Ask yourself, "Is this thought helping me or holding me back?" By acknowledging and challenging this thought, you can begin to separate it from the situation and cultivate a more balanced perspective. Remember, motivation is like a muscle that can be strengthened with practice, so try to focus on small, achievable goals and celebrate your progress, no matter how small.
column7: I understand that you're feeling unmotivated and weighed down, and it can be challenging to shake off that feeling. However, it's important to recognize that these thoughts are not the only possibilities in this situation. Instead of focusing on the weight that's holding you back, can you try to identify any small steps you can take to get moving? For example, you could start by setting a small, achievable goal for yourself, like taking a short walk or doing a quick task that you've been putting off. By breaking down larger tasks into smaller, more manageable steps, you may find that you're able to regain some of your energy and motivation. Additionally, try to challenge any negative self-talk that may be contributing to your feelings of unmotivation. Are there any positive affirmations or encouraging thoughts that you can focus on instead?
column8: Thank you for sharing your thoughts and insights with me. It's clear that you're actively reflecting on your current state of mind and exploring potential solutions. By acknowledging the possibility of a temporary rut and the potential underlying causes, you're taking a proactive approach to addressing your lack of motivation. I encourage you to continue exploring these avenues and to not be afraid to seek support from friends, family, or a professional if needed. Remember, it's okay to feel unmotivated at times, and it doesn't define your overall resilience and ability to move forward. Keep an open mind and be patient with yourself as you work through this challenging period. With time and effort, I'm confident that you'll find a way to rekindle your motivation and move forward in a positive direction.

column3: I just got fired from working as a sales person because I didn't reach my quota. I had never had a job like this before this. And I think I'm a failure and can't keep a sales person job.
column4: I just got fired from my job as a salesperson because I couldn't meet my quota. It's a role I've never had before and I can't help but feel like a failure. I'm starting to question if I'm really cut out for a salesperson job.
column5: I lost my sales job because I didn't meet the quota, which wasn't something I've encountered in my previous work life. While it's a setback, it doesn't necessarily mean I can't maintain a sales job. Maybe this particular sales role or the company's expectations weren't suitable for me. It could also be that I'm still acquiring the necessary skills and experience in this field. Alternatively, perhaps sales isn't my strong suit and I might excel in another line of work. Losing this job doesn't equate to failure, but rather a learning growth opportunity for future endeavors.
column6: It's understandable to feel upset and uncertain after being fired from a job, especially when it's a new role and you're struggling to meet expectations. However, it's important to separate this situation from your overall self-worth and identity as a person. Being fired from one job doesn't define your worth or potential as a salesperson or any other profession. It's okay to make mistakes and have setbacks, and it's important to learn from them. Rather than internalizing the situation and feeling like a failure, try to focus on what you can learn and how you can grow from this experience. What are some things you could do differently in the future to improve your performance? What are your strengths and weaknesses, and how can you leverage your strengths to succeed in a salesperson role? By focusing on the things you can control and learning from the experience, you can start to reframe your thinking and move forward with confidence.
column7: It's completely normal to feel overwhelmed and uncertain after experiencing a setback like losing your job. However, it's important to recognize that this one event does not define your worth or potential as a salesperson. Instead of dwelling on the negative thoughts of failure, let's brainstorm some alternative perspectives. What if this experience is an opportunity for you to explore other areas of sales that you may be more suited for? Or, what if this experience has taught you valuable skills that can be applied to other roles in the future? By shifting your focus to these possibilities, you may find that this setback can actually be a stepping stone for growth and success in the long run.
column8: "Thank you for sharing your thoughts and insights with me. It takes a lot of courage to confront challenges and re-evaluate our goals, and I commend you for taking this proactive step. It's important to recognize that setbacks like losing a job can be opportunities for growth and learning, rather than defining our worth. You've already identified some valuable perspectives, such as the possibility that the sales role or company may not have been a good fit, or that you may need to develop new skills and experience. I encourage you to continue exploring these ideas and to consider how they might inform your future career choices. Remember that you are not defined by one job or setback, but rather by your resilience, adaptability, and determination. Keep an open mind and a growth mindset, and don't be afraid to explore new possibilities and opportunities. You got this!"

column3: I keep pushing myself towards new things. I keep working, studying, socializing, exercising. I'm doing far more thab anyonr I know and I still go to sleep every night, hoping I won't wake up. And I think I'm everything I can and I still feel like shit
column4: I feel like I'm constantly pushing myself to do more and try new things, but no matter how much I accomplish, I still go to bed every night hoping I won't wake up. I've been putting in so much effort, but I still have this overwhelming feeling of emptiness and dissatisfaction. It's like nothing I do is ever enough to make me feel better.
column5: I am continuously seeking self-improvement by exploring various activities like work, study, and socializing. I'm highly committed, aligning my life with productive tasks and exercises frequently. Despite exceeding my own expectations and those of others, I battle with feelings of emptiness at the end of the day, wishing I won't open my eyes the next morning. Maybe I'm enduring too much; it might be the time to reassess my priorities. This constant feeling of discontent could be an indication that I'm possibly not focusing on the right things in life or not giving myself the credit I deserve. Instead of comparing my deeds with others, I should focus more on personal satisfaction, mental peace, and self-care.
column6: It's understandable to feel like you're not making progress or feeling satisfied with your accomplishments, especially when you're constantly pushing yourself to do more. However, it's important to recognize that these feelings are not necessarily a reflection of your worth or the value of your efforts. It's possible that you're holding yourself to unrealistically high standards, or that you're comparing yourself to others in an unhelpful way. By separating your thoughts from the situation, try to identify any distorted or unhelpful thinking patterns that may be contributing to these feelings. Ask yourself, is there a more balanced or realistic way to look at this situation? Are there other factors at play that could be contributing to these feelings? By reframing your thoughts in a more positive and realistic light, you may find that you're able to approach challenges with a more hopeful and resilient mindset.
column7: It sounds like you're struggling with a common phenomenon known as the "empty feeling" or "unfulfilled" state. It's important to recognize that this feeling is not a reflection of your worth or the effort you're putting in, but rather a sign that you may be focusing too much on external validation and not enough on your own internal fulfillment. Instead of constantly striving for more and better, try shifting your focus to what truly brings you joy and satisfaction. Ask yourself, "What are the things that make me feel alive and engaged? What are the things that I'm passionate about, and how can I incorporate them into my daily life?" By focusing on these things, you may find that you're able to cultivate a sense of fulfillment and purpose that doesn't rely on external validation.
column8:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It takes a lot of courage to acknowledge and express these emotions, and I'm here to support you. I can see that you've been putting in a lot of effort and striving for self-improvement, and that's something to be commended. However, it's important to recognize that self-worth and happiness cannot solely be measured by external accomplishments. It's possible that you're experiencing a common phenomenon known as the "hedonic treadmill," where no matter how much you achieve, you still feel a sense of emptiness or dissatisfaction.
I want you to know that it's okay to feel this way, and it doesn't mean that you're not doing enough or that you're not worthy of happiness. It's important to take a step back and reassess your priorities, as you mentioned. Instead of constantly striving for more, try to focus on cultivating a sense of inner peace and self-care. Practice self-compassion and self-forgiveness, and remind yourself that it's okay to take a break and prioritize your own needs.
Remember, happiness and fulfillment come from within, and it's important to nurture your mental health and well-being. I encourage you to explore activities that bring you joy and fulfillment, and to practice mindfulness and self-care. You deserve to feel happy and content, and I'm here to support you every step of the way.

column3: I know why I am so angry all of the time. like I have this little monster in my head. It just makes me want to abandon everything and hide from everyone so I lash out anymore. I just hate my brain. And I think I am crazy.
column4: I know why I am so angry all of the time. It's like there's this little monster in my head that just keeps brewing and making me want to push everyone away and isolate myself. I can't control my outbursts and it's starting to affect my relationships. I'm really frustrated with myself and I feel like I'm losing my mind.
column5: I am feeling intense anger and frustration frequently, it's as if there's a mischievous entity living within me, constantly pushing me to the edge. Perhaps there's an underlying reason that's yet to be understood, which may be causing this emotional turmoil. Sometimes, it feels like distancing from everything and everyone is the best solution, as a means to prevent any potential harm or discomfort to others. Instead of hating myself for these feelings, maybe I can learn to understand them better. I could be dealing with a mental health issue, and seeking help from a professional isn't a sign of being crazy, it's a step towards understanding and healing.
column6: It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and overwhelmed by your anger, but it's important to remember that you are not your anger. The little monster in your head is not a permanent fixture, and it's possible to learn how to manage and regulate your emotions in a healthy way. One strategy you can try is to notice when you're starting to feel angry, and take a step back to observe your thoughts without judgment. Ask yourself if there's a specific trigger or situation that's causing your anger, and try to find a more constructive way to respond to it. Remember that you don't have to act on every angry thought that comes up, and that you have the power to choose how you want to react. With practice and patience, you can learn to separate your thoughts from your emotions and manage your anger in a more positive way.
column7: It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of distress with these angry outbursts and feelings of being overwhelmed by a "little monster" in your head. It's important to recognize that these thoughts and feelings are not a reflection of your true self, but rather a sign that something is off-balance in your mind. Rather than trying to control or push away these thoughts, can we try to explore some other possibilities for how to manage them? For example, have you considered talking to a trusted friend or family member about how you're feeling? Or, have you tried engaging in some relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or meditation, to help calm your mind and body? By exploring these alternatives, we can work together to find a more constructive way to manage your emotions and improve your overall well-being.
column8:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It takes a lot of courage to confront and acknowledge the emotions that you're experiencing, and I commend you for taking this important step towards healing. It's clear that you're aware of the impact your anger is having on your relationships, and you're willing to explore ways to manage it.
I want to recognize that the little monster in your head is not something to be feared or hated, but rather something to be understood and worked with. It's possible that there are underlying issues or unresolved emotions that are contributing to this anger, and by exploring these issues, we can find ways to address them and find peace.
Remember that seeking help is not a sign of weakness, but rather a sign of strength and resilience. By working together, we can identify the root causes of your anger and find ways to manage it in a healthy and constructive way. You don't have to face this alone, and I'm here to support you every step of the way. Let's continue to explore these feelings and work towards finding a resolution that brings you peace and happiness.

column3: I left a toxic job that abused me for 12 years. I thought I found a new job that was better, but realized they lied to me about the job and now I hate working here. I feel like I made a huge mistake. And I think I can never get a break. Every time I try to make a positive change in my life, something happens to ruin it.
column4: I feel so frustrated and disappointed with myself. I finally had the courage to leave my toxic job after enduring 12 years of abuse. I thought I found a new opportunity that would be better for my well-being, but it turns out they lied to me about the job. Now I hate working here, and I can't help but feel like I made a huge mistake in leaving my previous job. It feels like I can never catch a break, whenever I try to make a positive change, something always happens to ruin it.
column5: While it's true that I left a toxic job and the new job hasn't turned out as expected, it also signals my ability to make changes in pursuit of my happiness. Perhaps this job isn't my ideal, but it's not the end. It's a stepping stone towards new possibilities. Sometimes things are not as they initially seem, this has uncovered my skills of recognizing unsuitable conditions. Yes, it seems difficult now, but that doesn't mean it will always be. Every experience is a chance to learn, grow, and develop resilience. This period of my life could be preparing me for something great in the future. A series of unfortunate events doesn't mean I will never get a break; it simply means the right opportunity is still out there waiting for me to discover it.
column6: It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and disappointed with yourself after experiencing a setback in your job search. However, it's important to recognize that this one event does not define your entire journey. Leaving a toxic job was a brave decision, and it takes courage to face the uncertainty of a new opportunity. Remember that setbacks are a normal part of life and can provide valuable learning experiences. Try to focus on the progress you've made so far and the steps you're taking to move forward. Instead of dwelling on the mistake of leaving your previous job, try to reframe it as an opportunity to learn and grow. Remember that you are not defined by this one event, and you have the power to create a better future for yourself.
column7: It's understandable to feel frustrated and disappointed when things don't go as planned, especially after making a significant change in your life. However, it's important to recognize that this experience is not a reflection of your worth or ability to make positive changes. Instead of dwelling on the negative, let's brainstorm some other possibilities that could have happened. For example, maybe the new job would have been even worse than your previous job, or maybe this experience will give you the opportunity to learn and grow in ways you never thought possible. By focusing on these alternative perspectives, you can begin to shift your mindset and see this experience as a chance for personal growth and development.
column8:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It takes a lot of courage to recognize when something isn't working for us and to make changes, even when it means leaving something familiar and comfortable. It's important to acknowledge the frustration and disappointment you're feeling, but also to recognize the strength and resilience you've shown in taking action towards a better situation.
It's true that sometimes things don't turn out as we expect, but that doesn't mean we've made a mistake. Every experience, including this one, is an opportunity to learn and grow. It's possible that this job wasn't the right fit for you, but it could also be a stepping stone towards something even better. Remember that you have the power to create the life you want, and every step you take towards that goal is a step in the right direction.
Keep in mind that it's okay to take time to figure things out and to make mistakes along the way. It's a normal part of the journey towards happiness and fulfillment. And while it may not feel like it right now, every experience, including this one, is preparing you for something great in the future. Keep an open mind and a positive attitude, and trust that the right opportunity will come along when the time is right.
Remember, you are not alone in this journey. I am here to support and guide you every step of the way. Keep talking and sharing your thoughts with me, and together we can work towards finding a solution that brings you happiness and fulfillment.

column3: I lost my best friend. I'm a male and she was the nicest girl I've ever met. But I fucked it. I started to take her for granted, started to overthink, to take everything too seriously, I was jealous, selfish and though only of my own interests and not of hers feelings And I think it's all my fault
column4: I feel like I've lost my best friend and it's all my fault. She was such a kind and amazing person, but I started to take her for granted. I became overly critical and started to overthink things. I was selfish and only focused on my own interests, completely disregarding her feelings. I can't help but blame myself for ruining our friendship.
column5: It's true that I've lost a cherished friendship, and I feel deeply responsible for the rupture. However, it's also just as possible that we both had a hand in what transpired. Possibly, she also had her faults and there was a lack of communication from both our ends. Maybe my jealousy and selfishness were not entirely unjustified - there could be circumstances I was reacting to that prompted these emotions. It's worth critically examining whether I was solely taking my interests into account or I was also involving her feelings but they were not reciprocated or understood. It might not be entirely my fault, as relationships are a two-way dynamic, and it could be a mixture of actions, words and circumstances from both sides that led to the fallout.
column6: It's understandable that you feel a sense of responsibility and guilt about the end of your friendship, but it's important to remember that you are not solely to blame for the situation. It's common for people to take their friends for granted and overlook their feelings, but it's important to recognize the complexity of the situation and the role that both parties played. Instead of beating yourself up over what you could have done differently, try to focus on what you can learn from this experience. Reflect on how you can improve your communication and empathy skills in future relationships, and try to cultivate a more mindful and compassionate approach to your interactions with others. Remember that you are not defined solely by this one experience, and that you have the capacity to grow and learn from it.
column7: It's understandable that you're feeling a lot of guilt and self-blame after losing your best friend. However, it's important to remember that no one person is perfect, and we all make mistakes in our relationships from time to time. Instead of beating yourself up over what you could have done differently, let's try to focus on the positive aspects of your friendship and the good times you shared together. What are some things that you and your friend enjoyed doing together? Can you think of any ways that you could honor her memory and keep her spirit alive? By shifting your focus to the positive, you may find it easier to process your grief and move forward in a healthy way.
column8:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It takes a lot of courage to confront the role we play in the demise of a relationship, and I commend you for being honest with yourself. It's important to recognize that relationships are complex and multifaceted, and it's rarely the case of one person being solely responsible for their downfall. It's possible that there were factors beyond your control that contributed to the breakdown of your friendship, and it's important to acknowledge those as well.
Rather than focusing solely on your own actions, try to approach this situation with a more nuanced perspective. Consider the possibility that there were unresolved issues or misunderstandings on both sides that led to the rift. By acknowledging and addressing these factors, you may be able to find closure and move forward in a more positive direction. Remember that you can't change the past, but you can learn from it and use that knowledge to improve your future interactions.
Remember that healing and growth often require time and effort, but it's possible to rebuild and strengthen relationships over time. Keep in mind that forgiveness is a process, and it may take time for both parties to come to a place of understanding and reconciliation. But with empathy, communication, and a willingness to work together, it's possible to rebuild and strengthen your friendship in the future.

column3: I lost my house And I think I want to die
column4: I lost my house and I think I want to die. I feel completely overwhelmed and hopeless. Everything I've worked for feels like it's been taken away from me.
column5: Losing my house is undoubtedly a severe setback, which has overwhelmed me with unexpected turmoil and despair. However, I need to remember that this is just a material loss, not the loss of my potential or my future. There are possibilities for me to recover from this disaster and recreate my life. It's going to be a challenge, but I have resilience within me. Now, I am focusing on exploring solutions, seeking help from government relief programs, friends, family, or community organizations. I also remember that it's essential to reach out to mental health professionals during this tough time to manage my emotions and thoughts effectively. Moreover, maybe this loss could open new doors for me to a simplified lifestyle or a new environment that I might end up appreciating more.
column6: It's understandable to feel overwhelmed and hopeless after experiencing a significant loss like losing your home. However, it's important to remember that this situation does not define your worth as a person. You are more than just the circumstances you find yourself in. It's okay to feel upset and to grieve the loss of your home, but try not to internalize the situation as a reflection of your own worth. Instead, focus on the things that are still within your control, such as your relationships with loved ones, your personal well-being, and your resilience in the face of adversity. Remember, you have survived difficult situations before and you can do so again. Let's work together to find ways to cope with this loss and to find a sense of hope and purpose moving forward.
column7: I understand that losing your home can be an incredibly difficult and overwhelming experience, and it's completely normal to feel hopeless and helpless in the face of such a significant loss. However, it's important to remember that this is not the end of your story. There are other possibilities and ways to cope with this situation. Have you considered reaching out to friends and family for support? They may be able to provide emotional support and help you find temporary housing until you get back on your feet. Additionally, there may be local organizations that can provide financial assistance and other resources to help you get through this difficult time. Remember, you are not alone and there are people and resources available to help you through this challenging period. Let's work together to brainstorm some other possibilities and find ways to move forward.
column8:
Dear [Patient's Name],
I can see that you're going through a very difficult time right now, and I want you to know that you're not alone in this. Losing your home can be an incredibly overwhelming experience, but it's important to remember that it's not a reflection of your worth or your future. You have shown great resilience in recognizing that this is a setback, but not a defining moment in your life. It takes a lot of courage to acknowledge that you need help, and I'm here to support you every step of the way.
I appreciate your brainstorming and the steps you're taking to move forward. Seeking help from government programs, friends, family, and community organizations is a great idea, and reaching out to mental health professionals is crucial to managing your emotions and thoughts during this time. It's important to remember that you don't have to go through this alone, and that there are people and resources available to help you through this difficult time.
It's also important to keep an open mind and be open to the possibilities that this loss could bring. Sometimes, unexpected setbacks can lead to new opportunities and a simpler lifestyle that we might end up appreciating more. I know it's hard to see right now, but there is hope for a brighter future, and I believe in you and your ability to overcome this challenge.
Remember, healing takes time, but you don't have to go through it alone. I'm here to support you every step of the way, and I have faith in your ability to overcome this difficult time. Please don't hesitate to reach out to me if you need anything.

column3: I love two people at the same time And I think That I'm going to fail
column4: I am really struggling right now. I have developed strong feelings for two different people, and it's tearing me apart. I feel so conflicted and I'm afraid that no matter what decision I make, I'm going to end up failing in some way. I don't know what to do or how to handle this situation.
column5: While it might feel overwhelming and confusing to have strong feelings for two people at the same time, it does not mean I am doomed for failure. This could potentially be an opportunity for me to discover more about myself and what I truly want in a relationship. Perhaps the feelings I have for these two people reflect different aspects of what I value and need. By consulting a psychologist, I am being proactive in understanding my emotions and learning how to effectively manage them. It's not a guarantee of disaster; rather, it could be a point of personal growth.
column6: It's completely normal to feel conflicted and uncertain when faced with difficult choices, especially when it comes to matters of the heart. It's important to remember that you are not defined by this situation, and that you have the power to make choices that align with your values and goals. Rather than getting caught up in the emotions of the moment, try to take a step back and assess the situation objectively. What are your values and priorities? What are the potential consequences of each option? By separating the situation from your thought, you can gain clarity and make a decision that is in line with your true desires and needs. Remember, it's okay to take your time and seek support from trusted friends, family, or a professional counselor as you navigate this challenging situation.
column7: It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and uncertain about how to navigate this complex situation. It's important to recognize that you're not alone in feeling this way, and that it's okay to feel conflicted. Rather than focusing on the negative thoughts and fears, let's try to brainstorm some other possibilities for how you can handle this situation. Have you considered talking to both people and being honest about your feelings? Or, have you thought about taking some time to reflect on what you want and need in a relationship? Sometimes, taking a step back and gaining some perspective can help us make decisions that are in line with our values and goals. What do you think?
column8:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It takes a lot of courage to acknowledge and confront these complex emotions, and I commend you for taking this step. It's important to recognize that having strong feelings for multiple people is not uncommon, and it doesn't necessarily mean that you're doomed to fail. In fact, this could be an opportunity for you to learn more about yourself and what you truly want in a relationship.
By exploring your feelings with a psychologist, you can gain a deeper understanding of your emotions and develop strategies for managing them in a healthy and constructive way. It's not always easy, but with time and effort, you can learn to navigate these complex emotions and find a path that works for you. Remember, personal growth and self-awareness are key to finding happiness and fulfillment in life, and I'm here to support you every step of the way.

column3: I made a goal to quit smoking and failed And I think I keep failing at this
column4: I made a goal to quit smoking and failed. I think I keep failing at this.
column5: It's true that I haven't been successful in my goal to quit smoking yet, but this does not necessarily mean I'm perpetually doomed to fail. Perhaps I need to approach this challenge from a different angle or try new methods to quit smoking. Maybe I can try nicotine gums, patches or seek support from counseling or support groups. I should also consider that overcoming addiction takes time and multiple attempts. Just because I didn't succeed this time doesn't mean I won't in the future. Failure is often part of the process to success.
column6: It's important to recognize that your thought of "I keep failing at quitting smoking" is not necessarily a reflection of your inherent ability to quit. Rather, it may be a reflection of the challenges and setbacks you've faced in your attempt to quit. It's common for people to experience setbacks when trying to make significant changes in their lives, and it doesn't mean that you're not capable of quitting smoking. Instead, try to focus on the progress you've made so far and the strategies that have worked for you in the past. Remember, quitting smoking is a process and it may take time and effort to overcome the urge to smoke. Keep in mind that you can always try again and learn from your past experiences to improve your approach.
column7: It's understandable to feel discouraged when you don't meet your goals, especially when it comes to something as challenging as quitting smoking. However, it's important to recognize that quitting is a process and it may take multiple attempts before you find what works for you. Instead of focusing on the failures, let's brainstorm some alternative perspectives on this situation. What if you view each attempt as an opportunity to learn and grow? What if you approach each attempt with a different strategy or mindset? What if you celebrate each small success, no matter how small, and use them as motivation to keep going? By shifting your focus away from the failures and towards the possibilities, you may find that the journey towards quitting smoking becomes more manageable and less daunting.
column8:
Thank you for sharing your brainstorming with me. It takes a lot of courage to acknowledge that you haven't been successful in your goal to quit smoking yet, and even more so to consider new approaches and strategies to achieve it. I completely agree with you that overcoming addiction is a process that requires time, effort, and multiple attempts. It's important to recognize that failure is not the end of the road, but rather a stepping stone towards success.
I would like to encourage you to keep exploring different methods and approaches to quitting smoking, and to be patient with yourself throughout the process. It's important to remember that quitting smoking is a journey, and it's okay to take it one step at a time. Consider seeking support from counseling or support groups, as they can provide valuable guidance and encouragement along the way.
Remember, every small step you take towards your goal is a step in the right direction. Keep pushing forward, and don't give up on yourself. You got this!

column3: I made a joke that fell flat in front of someone I just met, and that person left the room. And I think People will never perceive me as acting naturally in social situations.
column4: I made a joke that fell flat in front of someone I just met, and that person left the room. I feel embarrassed and worried that people will never perceive me as acting naturally in social situations.
column5: While it's true that I made a joke that didn't land with someone new and they left the room, it might not be as critical as I'm making it out to be. They could have left the room for reasons unrelated to my joke, perhaps they needed to use the restroom or received a message they needed to answer. It's unreasonable to believe that one uncomfortable social interaction will define all future encounters. Maybe people perceive me as someone who is not afraid to take risks in conversations or someone who has their unique sense of humor. Also, my 'acting naturally' is subjective to various perspectives; what seems unnatural to me might appeal to others. This could be an opportunity to recalibrate my approach, dispense humor more comfortably, and keep the situations light, to feel more natural and authentic to myself.
column6: "It's understandable to feel embarrassed or worried about a joke not going over well, especially in a new social situation. However, it's important to remember that one awkward moment does not define your entire social persona. Everyone has had moments where they've made a joke that didn't land, or said something they regret. The key is to learn from the experience and move on, rather than letting it dictate how you perceive yourself in social situations. Try to focus on the present moment and the people around you, rather than dwelling on the past. Remember, it's okay to make mistakes and it's important to be kind to yourself as you work through them."
column7: It's understandable to feel embarrassed and worried about a joke not going over well, especially in a new social situation. However, it's important to remember that humor is subjective and what one person finds funny, another might not. Instead of beating yourself up over it, try to focus on the fact that you were able to take a risk and be yourself in that moment. Every social interaction is an opportunity to learn and grow, and this experience can be a chance to practice being more mindful of your humor and how it might be received. Try to reframe the situation by brainstorming other possibilities, such as: "Maybe that person just wasn't in the mood for humor today, or maybe they appreciated the effort you put into the joke but it didn't land as well as you hoped. The important thing is to keep trying and to be kind to yourself along the way."
column8:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It takes a lot of courage to acknowledge and reflect on our social interactions, especially when they don't go as planned. I appreciate your willingness to brainstorm and challenge your negative thoughts.
You make some valid points. It's possible that the person who left the room had other reasons for doing so, and it's not necessarily a reflection on your joke. It's also important to remember that people perceive and respond to humor differently, and what may not land well with one person could be enjoyed by another.
Rather than beating yourself up over this one instance, try to use it as an opportunity to learn and grow. You could try experimenting with different types of humor or approaches to see what works best for you in different situations. And remember, it's okay to be yourself and take risks in social situations – it's how we learn and connect with others. Keep in mind that it's a process and it may take time to find your footing, but with practice and patience, you can develop your own unique sense of humor and social style.
Remember, you are not alone in this. Many people struggle with social anxiety and the fear of embarrassment, but with time and effort, you can learn to manage these feelings and become more confident in your social interactions. Keep pushing forward and know that you are making progress.

column4: I made a mistake with an expensive reagent at work and ruined my experiment. And I think I'm mad at myself for being careless.

column7: "I understand that you're feeling frustrated and mad at yourself for making a mistake with the expensive reagent. column8: Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It takes a lot of courage to acknowledge and confront our mistakes, and I commend you for doing so. By recognizing that everyone makes mistakes and that they can be opportunities for growth, you are taking a significant step towards self-compassion and personal improvement. It's important to remember that we are not defined by our mistakes, but rather by how we learn and grow from them. Instead of beating yourself up over this mishap, try to approach it with a growth mindset and see it as a chance to improve your skills and processes. column3: I made very good English presentation but I got nervous because of the amount of people and I forgot my text And I think I'm scared to present in front of other people and I panic
column4: I'm really struggling with my anxiety when it comes to public speaking. I recently had to do an English presentation, and even though I had prepared well, I got so nervous when I saw the large audience that I completely forgot my text. Now, I feel scared and panicky whenever I think about presenting in front of other people.
column5: While it's true that I got nervous and forgot my text during the presentation, I should also consider the fact that I managed to create a very good English presentation in the first place. This shows that I have knowledge, creativity, and skill. The nervousness could have been due to an unfamiliar situation or environment, which is something a lot of people face and can be managed with practice and preparation. It's possible that I'm not generally scared to present in front of others, but the amount of people this time was more than I was used to. Also, I may not necessarily panic in every presentation situation; this could have been a one-time occurrence. Instead of generalizing this one experience, I could look at it as an opportunity to learn and build my presentation skills further.
column6: It's completely normal to feel anxious when faced with a challenging situation like public speaking, especially if you've had a previous negative experience. However, it's important to recognize that your anxiety is not a reflection of your worth or ability. You are not your anxiety, and you have the power to separate your thoughts and emotions from the situation. Try to focus on the present moment and the task at hand, rather than worrying about what might happen in the future. Remember, you have prepared well and have the skills and knowledge to succeed. Take deep breaths, and try to approach the situation with a growth mindset, viewing it as an opportunity to learn and grow.
column7: It's completely normal to feel anxious when it comes to public speaking, especially when you've had a previous experience where you felt unprepared or forgot your words. However, instead of dwelling on that one instance, let's try to brainstorm some other possibilities for future presentations. What if you could focus on your strengths and the value you bring to the table? What if you could reframe your nerves as excitement and energy? What if you could see the audience as a supportive group of people who want you to succeed? By shifting your perspective and focusing on the positive, you may find that your anxiety subsides and you're able to approach future presentations with more confidence and ease.
column8:
Of course, I'm here to help you. I recognize that you've been struggling with anxiety when it comes to public speaking, particularly after your recent English presentation. However, I want to help you reframe your perspective on this experience. You're absolutely right that you managed to create a great presentation, and that's something to be proud of! It's completely normal to feel nervous in new or unfamiliar situations, and it's great that you're recognizing this.
Rather than focusing on the one-time occurrence of forgetting your text, let's look at it as an opportunity to learn and grow. With practice and preparation, you can build your confidence and skills in public speaking. Remember, every experience is a chance to improve and become a better presenter. So, let's work together to help you manage your anxiety and build your presentation skills. Are you up for that?

column3: I missed a personal deadline for a project a friend asked me to help with. And I think I made a deadline and missed it.
column4: I feel really disappointed in myself because I missed a personal deadline for a project that a friend asked me to help with. I had every intention of finishing it on time, but somehow I still managed to miss the deadline.
column5: It's possible that my friend understands my circumstances and is more lenient than I expect. Maybe this project wasn't as time-sensitive as I thought. Even though I missed the deadline, I can still complete the work and apologize for the delay. Perhaps there are factors contributing to my delay that I need to address, such as inefficient time management or too heavy of a workload. Maybe I need to start setting more realistic deadlines that accommodate my busy schedule. I could also consider involving others to help spread the work.
column6: It's understandable to feel disappointed in yourself when you don't meet a deadline, especially when it's for something important to someone else. However, it's important to recognize that missing a deadline doesn't define your entire self-worth. It's okay to make mistakes and have setbacks, and it's important to be kind to yourself as you learn from this experience. Instead of beating yourself up over the missed deadline, try to focus on what you can do differently in the future to avoid similar situations. Remember, you are more than one event or mistake, and you have the power to learn and grow from this experience.
column7: It's understandable to feel disappointed in yourself when you miss a deadline, especially when it's for something important to a friend. However, instead of dwelling on the missed deadline, let's try to brainstorm some other possibilities for how you can still help your friend with the project. For example, you could offer to help with a different aspect of the project, or you could suggest a different timeline that works better for you. By focusing on finding a solution rather than dwelling on the mistake, you can regain a sense of control and agency in the situation.
column8:
It's great to see you taking a proactive approach to addressing this situation, by brainstorming potential solutions and considering your friend's perspective. Recognizing that you had every intention of finishing the project on time and still managed to miss the deadline can be a challenging realization, but it's important to acknowledge and learn from it. By taking responsibility for your actions and identifying areas for improvement, you're already taking steps towards rectifying the situation.
It's important to remember that missed deadlines can happen to anyone, and it doesn't define your worth as a person or a friend. What's important is how you handle the situation moving forward. By being proactive, taking responsibility, and addressing any underlying issues, you can not only complete the project but also maintain a strong friendship.
Remember to be kind to yourself and acknowledge your efforts in trying to manage your workload and meet deadlines. It's okay to ask for help when needed, and involving others can often lead to better outcomes. Keep in mind that communication and empathy are key in any relationship, and being open and honest with your friend can help to strengthen your bond. Keep up the good work!

column3: I mixed up the addresses on two packages and sent them to the wrong place And I think I screwed up again at work

It's possible that I was simply distracted or stressed, which impacted my attention to detail. At other times, I've been thorough and accurate in my tasks. Making a mistake on occasions doesn't reflect my overall job performance. It's important to acknowledge the mistake, learn from it, and find strategies to avoid similar mistakes in the future, such as double-checking addresses before sending out packages. I should not let one instance of error define my abilities or performance at work.
column6: It's understandable to feel overwhelmed and stressed when you make a mistake like this, but try to separate the situation from your thought. Making a mistake at work doesn't define your entire self-worth. It's important to remember that everyone makes mistakes, and it's how you learn and grow from them that matters. Instead of beating yourself up over this, try to focus on what you can do to prevent it from happening again in the future. What steps can you take to improve your organizational skills and attention to detail? By focusing on the steps you can take to improve, you can start to shift your mindset away from the negative thoughts and towards a more positive and productive one.
column7:

Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that mistakes happen to everyone, and it doesn't define your worth or competence as a person or an employee. column8:

column3: I posted a new piece of artwork online and people started comparing it with artwork created by others And I think I shouldn't have posted it
column4: I posted a new piece of artwork online and people started comparing it with artwork created by others. I can't help but feel like I shouldn't have posted it. It's making me doubt myself and my abilities as an artist.
column5: Posting my artwork online is a step towards sharing my creativity with the world. Although the comparison with other artists feels disheartening, it can also serve as an opportunity to learn and grow in my artistic journey. Moreover, every artist has a unique style and perspective, making each piece valuable in its own right. The fact that people engaged with my artwork and made comparisons speaks volumes about its impact. This experience can be a stepping stone to embracing different perspectives and growing my resilience. Ultimately, it is a measure of my courage in expressing my creative self to the world. Whether or not the critics appreciate it or compare it, the most important thing is that it's a reflection of my unique voice and creativity.
column6: It's completely normal to feel self-doubt when others compare your work to that of others, especially when it's on a public platform like social media. However, it's important to remember that comparison is the thief of joy and creativity. Focus on your own unique style and voice, rather than comparing yourself to others. Every artist has their own distinct perspective and vision, and that's what makes their work special. Instead of dwelling on the comparisons, try to focus on the positive feedback and support you've received from others. Remember, the only opinion that truly matters is your own, and as long as you're creating from a place of passion and authenticity, you're already ahead of the game. Keep creating and don't let the opinions of others hold you back from expressing yourself fully.
column7: It's completely normal to feel self-doubt when comparing yourself to others, especially when it comes to creative work. However, it's important to remember that everyone has their own unique style and perspective, and comparison can be misleading. Instead of focusing on the similarities between your work and others, try to identify what makes your artwork unique and special. What are some elements that you bring to the table that others might not? What message do you want to convey through your artwork? By focusing on these questions, you can shift your mindset from comparison to creativity and self-expression. Remember, the only way to truly grow as an artist is to keep creating and sharing your work, regardless of what others may think. So, don't be afraid to keep posting and sharing your artwork, and trust that your unique voice and perspective will shine through.
column8:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It takes a lot of courage to share your creative work with the world, and it's completely normal to feel vulnerable and exposed when it's met with feedback, whether positive or negative. However, as you brainstormed, it's important to recognize that comparison is a natural part of the creative process. Every artist has their own unique style and perspective, and the fact that people are engaging with your work and making comparisons is a testament to its impact.
Rather than viewing comparison as a source of doubt, try to see it as an opportunity to learn and grow. What can you learn from the other artists whose work you're comparing yourself to? How can you incorporate those lessons into your own creative process? Remember, the most important thing is to stay true to your unique voice and creativity. Your art is a reflection of your unique perspective and experiences, and that's what makes it valuable and meaningful.
Keep in mind that resilience is built through experiences like this, where you face challenges and learn to navigate them. By embracing the process and staying committed to your creative vision, you'll become a stronger and more confident artist. Keep creating, and don't be afraid to share your work with the world.

column3: I put in a lot of time on an Mturk task and was rejected on an attention request. I suggested a better way of handling these errors (automatic ejection) to the researcher and their answer showed they didn't understand my point. And I think I didn't explain this right.
column4: I'm feeling really frustrated and upset right now. I spent a lot of time working on a task on Mturk, and my attention to detail was apparently not good enough because my work got rejected. I thought I had a good idea for how to handle these types of errors, so I reached out to the researcher to suggest an automatic ejection system. But their response made me feel like they didn't understand my point, and now I'm starting to doubt if I explained myself clearly.
column5: I spent considerable hours on an Mturk task, only to face rejection due to a disattention request error. I approached the researcher with an improved methodology for managing these mishaps, namely, automatic ejection. Their response, however, indicated a clear misunderstanding of my recommendation. Rather than blaming my explaining skills, perhaps they're not accustomed with such suggestions or simply lacking adequate comprehension skills. Another possibility could be a language barrier or perhaps they're already considering a similar solution. It's important to remember not all communication discrepancies are a reflection of my eloquence or articulation capabilities.

However, it's important to separate this situation from your thought that you didn't explain yourself clearly. column3: I received a rejection email from a position I applied to. And I think I will never get a job.
column4: I received a rejection email from a position I applied to, and it has been really discouraging. It makes me question my abilities and wonder if I will ever be able to find a job. I feel like I'm never going to be successful in my career.
column5: Although I didn't secure this particular job, there are a host of other job opportunities available that could potentially be a better fit for me. Not getting this job doesn't imply that I am unfit for other roles. Instead, it could be that the role was not a perfect fit for my skills or experience level. Every rejection is a step towards the right direction as it is an opportunity to learn and improve. Failure is often a stepping stone towards success and not the endpoint. Next time, I'll make sure to prepare better and focus on improving my interview skills. I'm confident that I will find a job that suits me best.
column6: It's understandable to feel discouraged and question your abilities after receiving a rejection email, but it's important to remember that this one email does not define your worth or your future success. It's important to separate this situation from your overall identity and self-worth. You are more than this one rejection, and there are many factors that can contribute to not getting a job, including the competitive nature of the job market and the fact that it's okay to face rejection in life. It's important to focus on the things that you can control, such as your attitude, your skills, and your efforts, and to keep working towards your goals. Remember that success is often a marathon, not a sprint, and it's okay to experience setbacks along the way. Keep things in perspective, and try to focus on the positive aspects of your life and your abilities.
column7: It's completely normal to feel discouraged after receiving a rejection email, but it's important to remember that this one email does not define your worth or your future success. Remember, rejection is a normal part of the job search process, and every successful person has experienced it at some point.
