column7: It's understandable to feel anxious and disappointed after a job interview, but it's important to remember that not hearing back right away doesn't necessarily mean you didn't get the job. It's possible that the hiring process is taking longer than expected, or that they are still reviewing applications. Instead of focusing on the negative thought of not getting the job, can we brainstorm some other possibilities? For example, maybe you made a great impression and the interviewer will follow up with you soon, or maybe you will get an offer from another company that is even better suited for you. Let's try to focus on the positive aspects and see if we can't shift your thinking to a more hopeful perspective.
column8:
Of course, I'm here to help you process your thoughts and feelings. It's completely normal to feel anxious and disappointed when you're waiting to hear back about a job interview, especially when you've put in a lot of effort and time into the application process. However, as you've brainstormed, there are several factors that could be contributing to the delay in hearing back from the hiring team. It's important to keep in mind that the hiring process can be lengthy and unpredictable, and it's not always a reflection on your qualifications or worth as a candidate.
Remember, you've done everything you can to prepare for the interview and to present yourself in the best possible light. Now, it's out of your hands, and all you can do is wait patiently and hope for the best. Try to focus on the things that are within your control, like your ongoing job search and your personal well-being. By taking care of yourself and staying positive, you'll be better equipped to handle any outcome.
I understand that this can be a challenging time for you, but I believe in your resilience and ability to bounce back from any setbacks. Keep me updated on how you're feeling, and let's work together to find ways to manage your anxiety and stay motivated during this time.

column3: Threw a conniption when unable to complete an Amigurumi project for my niece. And I think I am unable to do this simply damned thing.
column4: I am feeling extremely frustrated and angry because I was unable to finish an Amigurumi project for my niece. I've been trying for a while now, but it seems like I just can't do it. It's really starting to make me feel incapable and frustrated with myself.
column5: While I did experience an intense bout of frustration when I failed to complete this Amigurumi project, I remind myself that it's okay to not be good at everything. This particular task may have taken more skill and patience than I previously anticipated. Maybe I can look for simpler projects in the beginning to gradually build my skills. It's also possible to seek instructional videos or join crafting groups that can help me improve. Moreover, my value isn't solely determined by my ability to complete this project. I have other skills and qualities that I can appreciate and focus on. Lastly, it might encourage me to understand that failure is often a stepping stone to success.
column6: It's understandable to feel frustrated and angry when we're unable to complete a task, especially when it's something we're passionate about like making an Amigurumi project for your niece. However, it's important to remember that not being able to finish something doesn't define our worth or capabilities as a person. It's okay to make mistakes and have setbacks, and it's important to be kind to ourselves and not beat ourselves up over it. Instead of focusing on the failure to finish the project, try to identify what specifically is causing the frustration and see if there are any steps you can take to address it. Maybe there are certain techniques or skills you need to learn, or maybe you just need to take a break and come back to it with a fresh perspective. Remember, it's okay to not be perfect and to take things one step at a time.
column7: It's understandable to feel frustrated and disappointed when we're unable to complete a project, especially one that's important to someone we care about. Instead of focusing on the sense of incapability, can we try to brainstorm some other possibilities? For example, what if you took a break from the project for a little while and came back to it with fresh eyes? Or, what if you broke the project down into smaller, more manageable tasks, and worked on one task at a time? By reframing the situation in this way, you may find that the task becomes less overwhelming and more achievable. Additionally, it might be helpful to acknowledge and validate your feelings, rather than trying to suppress or deny them. By doing so, you may find that you're able to approach the project with a more positive mindset and a greater sense of confidence.
column8:
Of course, I'm here to help you process your feelings and find ways to move forward. It's completely normal to feel frustrated and disappointed when we encounter obstacles, especially when it comes to something we're passionate about like crafting. By recognizing that it's okay to not be good at everything and acknowledging that this project may have been more challenging than you anticipated, you've taken an important step towards reframing your perspective.
It's great that you're considering simpler projects to build your skills and seeking out resources like instructional videos or crafting groups to help you improve. Remember that learning and growth are ongoing processes, and it's okay to take things at your own pace.
I also appreciate your reminder that your value as a person isn't solely determined by your ability to complete this project. You have many wonderful qualities and skills that make you unique and valuable, and it's important to focus on those as well.
Finally, you're right that failure can often be a stepping stone to success. Sometimes, it takes a setback to motivate us to try harder and find new ways to achieve our goals. column3: Time is running short on the workday, my boss asks me if I can finish a task that will require me to stay for a few extra hours. And I think Why would you wait until the last minute to ask me this.
column4: I feel frustrated and overwhelmed when my boss asks me at the last minute to stay for a few extra hours to finish a task. I can't help but wonder why they didn't mention it earlier when there was still ample time to complete it.
column5: Instead of focusing on the negative thoughts about my boss's timing, I could consider the fact that I'm valued enough in my position that he/she trusts me with this important task. Additionally, this could also be seen as an excellent opportunity to showcase my dedication and work ethic, which could be beneficial for my future career advancement. Furthermore, this could be interpreted as a sign of faith in my capability to solve problems under tight deadlines. Finally, not everything is planned, it can be a last-minute emergency where my skills were needed most for the company's benefit.
column6: It's understandable to feel frustrated when unexpected tasks are added at the last minute, especially when it disrupts your schedule. However, it's important to recognize that your boss's request is not a personal attack on you, but rather a reflection of the demands of the job. It's possible that your boss was not aware of the time constraints or did not want to burden you with the task earlier in the day. By separating the situation from your thought, try to reframe your thinking to focus on the task at hand and the reasons why your boss asked for your help. Remember that you are a valuable member of the team and your contributions are appreciated.
column7: It's understandable to feel frustrated when unexpected tasks are added at the last minute, especially when it disrupts your schedule. However, instead of dwelling on why your boss didn't communicate earlier, let's brainstorm some alternative thoughts that could help you approach this situation more constructively. For example, you could think, "This is an opportunity for me to show my boss that I'm reliable and can handle unexpected tasks with ease." Or, "I can use this extra time to work on a personal project or learn a new skill, which can benefit me in the long run." By shifting your focus to these positive possibilities, you may find it easier to manage your frustration and approach the task with a more productive mindset.
column8: Thank you for sharing your thoughts and insights with me. It's clear that you've been able to identify some positive aspects of your boss's request, and that's a great step towards reframing your perspective. By recognizing the value your boss places in your work and the potential benefits of taking on this challenge, you may find it easier to approach the situation with a more positive mindset. Remember that sometimes, things don't always go as planned, and being adaptable and flexible can be a valuable asset in any workplace. Keep in mind that your boss's request is an opportunity for you to showcase your skills and dedication, and I'm sure you'll be able to rise to the challenge. Keep up the good work!

column3: We had bad storms in our community and some tornadoes came through and destroyed some of the area. No one in our extended family from out of town checked on me. And I think I feel unloved and unwanted by my mother and siblings
column4: I'm feeling really hurt and upset after the storms in our community. It's been tough, and what's been bothering me is that none of my extended family from out of town reached out to check on me. It's making me wonder if they really care about me. And it's not just them, I also feel unloved and unwanted by my mother and siblings.
column5: Despite the fact that my mother and siblings did not check on me after the recent storms and tornadoes, it is possible that they were facing their own challenges or disruptions. Perhaps, they are assuming that I was not largely affected since they didn't hear anything specifically from me about the situation. Their lack of contact may not necessarily mean that they do not care about me, rather it could be a sign of their trust in my ability to handle difficult situations. Additionally, feelings of being unloved and unwanted might have deep roots than this situation, and it could be beneficial to explore these feelings in a therapeutic setting.
column6: It's understandable that you're feeling hurt and upset after the recent storms in your community, and it's natural to feel supported and cared for during difficult times. However, it's important to separate your thoughts about your extended family not reaching out from the situation itself. It's possible that they may be dealing with their own challenges and may not have had the opportunity or resources to check in with you. Additionally, it's important to remember that your worth and value as a person are not defined by the actions of your family members. You are loved and valued regardless of their actions, and it's okay to feel upset or hurt, but try not to internalize those feelings as a reflection of your worth. Is there anything else you'd like to talk about or any other thoughts you'd like to share?
column7: It's understandable to feel hurt and upset after the recent storms in your community, and it's natural to feel a sense of isolation and disconnection from your loved ones. However, it's important to remember that their lack of reach out doesn't necessarily mean they don't care about you. It's possible that they may be dealing with their own challenges and struggles, or they may not have had the opportunity to check in with you yet. Instead of jumping to conclusions, try to focus on the things that you can control and take action on. Have you tried reaching out to them directly to check in and see how they're doing? Sometimes, a simple act of reaching out can go a long way in rebuilding connections and strengthening relationships. Additionally, try to focus on the things that you are grateful for in your life, such as your support system, your home, and your overall well-being. By shifting your focus to the positive aspects of your life, you may find that your feelings of hurt and isolation begin to lift.
column8:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It takes a lot of courage to confront these challenging emotions, and I'm here to support you every step of the way. I can see that you've been through a difficult time recently, and it's understandable that you're feeling hurt and upset about the lack of support from your extended family. However, I want to help you see that their lack of contact might not necessarily mean they don't care about you. It's possible that they were dealing with their own challenges and didn't know how to reach out, or they might have assumed that you were handling things on your own.
It's important to remember that you are not alone in this. Many people in your community have been through similar experiences, and it's okay to feel overwhelmed and unsure of how to cope. By exploring these feelings in a therapeutic setting, we can work together to find ways to manage them and find support. You deserve to feel loved and wanted, and I'm here to help you find that support. Let's continue to work on this together, and see how we can help you feel more connected and supported.

column3: When I told my friend about my job, he said it has little real-world significance And I think My job is worthless
column4: When I told my friend about my job, he said it has little real-world significance. It made me question the value of what I do. I can't help but feel like my job is worthless.
column5: While my friend may have said that they view my job as having little real-world significance, I could consider this as one perspective out of many. Perhaps my friend is not fully aware of what my job entails and the impacts it has. I could bring to mind the times when my work has benefited others or contributed positively to the society. It is also possible that my job’s value is not easily seen or understood by people who are not directly involved in my field. Large societal changes often are gradual and hard for one person to see. Alternatively, if there's a recurring theme of feeling undervalued in my work, it may be beneficial to reassess my career path and consider whether a different job could bring more personal satisfaction.
column6: It's understandable to feel upset when someone questions the value of your work, especially when it comes from someone you trust. However, it's important to remember that one person's opinion doesn't define the worth of your job. Your work has value and meaning, regardless of what others may think. It's important to focus on the positive aspects of your job and the ways in which it contributes to society, rather than getting caught up in the opinions of others. Try to reframe your thinking by focusing on the things that you find fulfilling and meaningful about your work, and remind yourself that your efforts are making a difference in some way.
column7: It's understandable to feel uncertain or question the value of your work after hearing someone else's opinion, especially from a friend. However, it's important to remember that every job has its own unique purpose and significance, even if it may not be immediately apparent to others. Can you think of any ways in which your job contributes to society or helps people in some way? For example, does it provide a service, create something, or solve problems? By focusing on the positive aspects of your work, you may be able to shift your perspective and feel more confident in the value of what you do.
column8:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It's completely normal to question the value of our work at times, especially when others don't seem to appreciate its significance. However, it's important to remember that every job has its own unique value and purpose, and it's up to each individual to determine what that is. By considering different perspectives and brainstorming ways to recognize the value of your work, you've already taken an important step towards revaluating your job.
It's great that you're thinking about how your work has benefited others and contributed to society, as this can help you see the bigger picture. Additionally, it's important to remember that large societal changes often do take time and may not be immediately apparent to everyone.
If you're still feeling undervalued in your work, it may be worth exploring other career options that align more closely with your personal values and goals. But for now, let's focus on recognizing and appreciating the value of the work you're doing, and finding ways to make it more fulfilling for you. How does that sound?

column3: When doing some piecework online, I was told that my work was not good. And I think I worked hard on these jobs, and was sure I had done well.
column4: I feel really discouraged and frustrated right now. I recently received feedback on some piecework jobs I did online and was told that my work wasn't good enough. I put a lot of effort into these jobs and I was actually confident that I had done well.
column5: It's possible that the person reviewing my work may not have fully understood or appreciated the effort and creativity I put into it. Their judgement could have been influenced by their personal taste or their interpretation of the guidelines given. On another note, there may have been a minor misunderstanding, a communication gap, or even a technical issue that affected the assessment of my work. It might also be a learning chance, giving me an opportunity to ask for in-depth feedback and improve the quality of my future work. One shouldn't forget that even successful people have faced setbacks and rejection in their lives, and it's all part of personal and professional growth.
column6: It's understandable to feel discouraged and frustrated when we don't meet our own expectations, especially when we've put a lot of effort into something. However, it's important to remember that one piece of feedback or one situation doesn't define your entire abilities or worth. It's possible that the feedback you received was specific to that particular task or situation, and it doesn't necessarily reflect your overall performance or potential. Try to separate the situation from your thought by acknowledging the feedback and your feelings, but also reminding yourself of your strengths and accomplishments in other areas. It's okay to make mistakes and have areas for improvement, and it's important to be kind to yourself and focus on your growth and development moving forward.
column7: I understand that you're feeling discouraged and frustrated after receiving feedback on your online piecework. It's important to recognize that this one piece of feedback doesn't define your entire work or worth. Instead of dwelling on the negative, can we brainstorm some other possibilities for how you could approach this situation? For example, you could try to identify what specifically was lacking in your work and use that as an opportunity to learn and improve. You could also try to focus on the positive aspects of your work and the skills you have developed, and recognize that mistakes and imperfections are a natural part of the learning process. By shifting your perspective and focusing on the bigger picture, you may find that you're able to move past this setback and continue to grow and develop as a worker and a person.
column8:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It sounds like you're feeling quite discouraged and frustrated with the feedback you received on your work. I can understand why, as it can be difficult to hear that our efforts haven't met expectations. However, I want to encourage you to consider the possibility that the person reviewing your work may not have fully appreciated the effort and creativity you put into it. It's important to remember that everyone has their own biases and perspectives, and their judgement may have been influenced by these factors.
Additionally, it's possible that there was a minor misunderstanding or technical issue that affected the assessment of your work. Rather than letting this feedback discourage you, I encourage you to view it as an opportunity to learn and grow. Many successful people have faced setbacks and rejection in their careers, but they didn't let it hold them back. They used these experiences as opportunities to learn and improve, and I'm sure you can do the same.
Remember, you are not defined by one piece of feedback or one setback. You are a capable and talented individual with a lot to offer, and I have no doubt that you will continue to grow and succeed in your endeavors. Keep in mind that every setback is an opportunity to learn and improve, and don't be afraid to ask for in-depth feedback to help you grow. Keep pushing forward and stay positive, you got this!

column3: While I was at work, my supervisor questioned my decision in a negative tone infront of my peers. And I think She needs to stop discussing this.
column4: While I was at work, my supervisor questioned my decision in a negative tone in front of my peers. And I think she needs to stop discussing this. It made me feel embarrassed and undermined. I believe that my decision was valid and I don't appreciate being called out in that way. I want to find a way to address this situation and assert myself without causing further conflict.
column5: My supervisor may have questioned my decision in front of my colleagues because she thought it was an educational moment for everyone. She potentially believed the situation could be a learning opportunity. Her tone may have been unintentionally harsh, or possibly, I could be overanalyzing her tone due to feeling put on the spot. Maybe I can discuss the situation with her privately, express my feelings, and ask for future conversations to be handled differently. Rather than her stopping to discuss altogether, we could work towards a more productive form of communication.
column6:
It's understandable that you feel embarrassed and undermined by your supervisor's negative tone during the meeting. However, it's important to separate the situation from your thought about it. The situation is the specific event that occurred, which was your supervisor questioning your decision in front of your peers. Your thought is the emotional reaction you had to the situation, which is feeling embarrassed and undermined.
It's important to recognize that your supervisor's behavior was not a reflection of your decision's validity, but rather their own way of expressing their concerns. It's possible that they were simply trying to have an open and honest discussion about the decision, rather than attacking you personally.
Rather than focusing on how you want to assert yourself without causing further conflict, try to focus on the specific actions you can take to address the situation. For example, you could have a private conversation with your supervisor to understand their concerns and find a resolution. By separating the situation from your thought, you can approach the situation with a clearer and more level-headed mindset.
column7: It's completely understandable that you feel embarrassed and undermined by your supervisor's negative tone in front of your peers. However, instead of focusing on the negative, let's try to brainstorm some other possibilities for how you could address this situation. For example, you could calmly and confidently speak with your supervisor privately after the meeting to express your feelings and concerns about how they were addressed in front of others. You could also consider seeking support from a colleague or mentor to help you navigate this situation and assert yourself in a constructive way. Remember, you have the right to be respected and heard in the workplace, and it's okay to stand up for yourself in a professional and assertive manner.
column8:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It sounds like you're feeling frustrated and undermined by your supervisor's tone during the conversation at work. I can understand why you would want to assert yourself and find a way to address the situation without causing further conflict.
It's important to recognize that your supervisor may have had good intentions in questioning your decision in front of your peers. Perhaps she was trying to provide constructive feedback and create a learning opportunity for everyone involved. However, it's also important to acknowledge that her tone may have come across as harsh and embarrassing, and that's understandably upsetting for you.
Rather than asking your supervisor to stop discussing the situation altogether, it might be more productive to have a private conversation with her about how you're feeling. By expressing your feelings and concerns in a calm and respectful manner, you may be able to find a way to address the issue and improve the communication moving forward.
Remember, assertiveness and communication are key to resolving conflicts and finding a solution that works for everyone involved. By being open and honest about your feelings, you may be able to find a way to address the situation in a way that works for you and your supervisor.

column3: While in a group voice chat, everyone left me without saying goodbye. And I think Does nobody want to talk to me?
column4: I feel really hurt and confused right now. I was in a group voice chat and suddenly everyone left without saying goodbye. It made me question if anyone actually wants to talk to me.
column5: Perhaps they all had urgent matters to tend to simultaneously, and simply forgot to say goodbye due to their rush. There might have been connectivity issues that caused them all to suddenly drop out. Maybe they assumed I would need to leave soon as well and didn't want to disturb me. It could just be a coincidence rather than a deliberate act towards me. It might also be that they feel comfortable enough with me to end conversations casually, without formal goodbyes.
column6: It's understandable that you feel hurt and confused after being suddenly left out of a group voice chat without any goodbyes. However, it's important to remember that one person's actions do not define your worth or the value of your relationships. It's possible that the other person(s) had their own reasons for leaving, and it doesn't necessarily mean that they don't want to talk to you. Try not to take their actions personally and focus on the positive relationships and interactions you have with others. Remember, you are not defined by any one situation or interaction, and you have the power to choose how you respond to it.
column7: It's understandable to feel hurt and confused when someone suddenly leaves a group chat without saying goodbye. It's important to remember that one person's actions don't define your worth or the value of your relationships. Instead of jumping to conclusions, try to brainstorm other possibilities that could have led to their sudden departure. Maybe they were dealing with a personal issue and didn't have the time or energy to say goodbye, or maybe they simply didn't realize the impact their actions would have on you. By focusing on these alternative explanations, you can begin to shift your perspective and move away from negative thoughts and feelings. Remember, you deserve to be treated with respect and kindness, and it's okay to communicate your feelings and boundaries in a group setting.
column8:
Of course, I'm here to help you process this situation. It's completely understandable to feel hurt and confused when someone suddenly leaves a conversation without saying goodbye. It's important to recognize that their actions may not necessarily be a reflection of you or your worth. It might even be beneficial to ask for help, as others may have encountered a similar problem and they could provide new insight. column3: Would my death have an impact on people? Like is there anyone on here that's had someone close to them commit suicide and knows what it's like? And I think Would anyone care if I died?
column4: I've been having these thoughts lately that make me wonder about the impact my death would have on people. I can't help but question if anyone would truly care if I were no longer here. It's been making me feel somewhat isolated and hopeless.
column5: I might feel like nobody would care if I disappeared, but identifying those in my life who would be impacted if I were gone could help me realize I do matter to people. There are probably more people who care about me than I realize in my current state of mind. Alternatively, instead of focusing on my death, I could consider the positive impacts I can make on people's lives while I'm alive. We all leave marks on others' lives in ways we never know. I could also explore whether my feelings of worthlessness are a product of my depression and not reflective of my true value. What if I tried to reach out to someone trustworthy about what I'm feeling? Professional help could provide strategies for managing these thoughts.
column6: It's understandable to have thoughts about the impact of your death on others, but it's important to remember that these thoughts are not necessarily reflective of how people truly feel. It's possible that your loved ones may feel a sense of loss and sadness if you were to pass away, but it's also likely that they will find ways to cope and move forward without you. It's important to remember that you are not defined solely by your thoughts and feelings, and that you have value and worth beyond your own existence. Try to challenge these thoughts by asking yourself if there is any evidence to support them, and if there are any other ways of looking at the situation. Is there anything else you can think of that might be contributing to these thoughts?
column7: It's completely understandable to have these thoughts and feelings, especially when life can be challenging and overwhelming at times. However, it's important to remember that you are not alone in this, and that there are people who care about you and would be impacted by your passing. Rather than focusing on the negative thoughts, let's try to brainstorm some other possibilities and perspectives on this situation. For example, what are some things that you are grateful for in your life? Are there any positive relationships or experiences that you could focus on? How might your loved ones feel if they knew how much they mean to you? By shifting your focus to these more positive aspects, you may find that your feelings of isolation and hopelessness begin to lift.
column8: Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It takes a lot of courage to confront these difficult emotions, and I'm here to support you. I recognize that it can be challenging to see the value of your own life when you're struggling with depression, but I want you to know that you are not alone, and there are people who care about you deeply. By brainstorming and identifying those in your life who would be impacted if you were gone, you've taken an important step towards recognizing your value and worth. It's also important to remember that your feelings of worthlessness may be a product of your depression, and with professional help, you can learn strategies to manage these thoughts and improve your mental health. Reaching out to someone trustworthy, such as a therapist or a close friend, can provide you with a safe and supportive space to explore these feelings and work towards healing. Remember, you are not alone, and there are people who care about you and want to help.

column3: a girl i really liked would not go out on a date with me And I think im not very attractive
column4: I'm feeling really down because there's this girl I really liked, but she didn't want to go out on a date with me. It's making me question my attractiveness and self-esteem.

Perhaps I should broaden my social circle to meet new people. Also, I can focus on personal growth and self-improvement such as honing my personal strengths, or taking up a new hobby, which can improve my self-confidence.

However, it's important to remember that one person's decision doesn't define your worth or attractiveness as a person. It's possible that the girl you liked simply didn't feel the same way, and that's okay. Try not to take it personally or internalize it as a reflection of your self-worth. Instead, focus on the things that make you unique and special, and keep moving forward with your life. Remember, there are plenty of people out there who may be a great match for you, and you deserve to find someone who appreciates you for who you are.

For example, maybe the girl was just not interested in dating right now, or maybe she was shy or nervous and didn't know how to decline your invitation. The important thing is to focus on the present moment and not let this one rejection hold you back from exploring other opportunities and experiences. What are some other things you could do to boost your self-esteem and confidence?
column8:

It's understandable to feel apprehensive about the human mind and people, especially when there have been negative experiences in the past. However, it's important to remember that not everyone is the same, and it's possible to build trust and form meaningful connections with others.
By educating yourself about the human mind and participating in positive group environments, you can gain a better understanding of how people work and develop healthy relationships. It's also important to remember that trust is something that can be built over time, and it's okay if it doesn't happen overnight.
As a psychologist, I'm here to support you in your journey towards building trust and improving your mental health. Together, we can work on developing coping mechanisms and strategies to help you manage your fears and anxieties. Remember, you don't have to face this alone, and with time and effort, you can learn to trust yourself and others.

column3: it's so hard to do school work, get out of bed, care for myself, and eat And I think I'm so exhausted
column4: I feel overwhelmed and exhausted. It's becoming really difficult for me to do simple everyday tasks like school work, getting out of bed, taking care of myself, and even eating.
column5: While it's certainly challenging to tackle school work, self-care, and manage daily routine, there might be other approaches to consider that could ease the burden. Maybe I should consider seeking support from friends or family, or look into accessing school counseling or tutoring resources that could help me manage my workload better. Possibly, trying to implement a more structured schedule could helps me get out of bed and accomplish routine tasks. Engaging in daily physical activities could also help boost my energy levels. It might also be beneficial to consult with a doctor regarding potential physical health concerns that may be contributing to my constant exhaustion. Perhaps, my diet is lacking in some essential nutrients that could help me feel less tired.
column6: It's understandable to feel overwhelmed and exhausted when facing challenges in daily life. However, it's important to recognize that these feelings are not necessarily a reflection of your abilities or worth as a person. Rather, they may be a response to the situation you're in. Try to separate the situation from your thought by acknowledging that these feelings are temporary and can be managed. You have the power to take small steps towards managing your workload, taking breaks when needed, and seeking support from loved ones. Remember, you are not alone in this and there are resources available to help you cope. By practicing self-compassion and reframing your thoughts, you can work towards feeling more grounded and in control.
column7: It sounds like you're feeling really overwhelmed and struggling to manage your daily tasks. It's important to remember that you don't have to do this alone. Can we brainstorm some ways to make these tasks more manageable and less overwhelming? For example, can you break down your school work into smaller, more manageable chunks, or find a study buddy to help you stay on track? Are there any small things you can do each day to take care of yourself, like taking a short walk or practicing deep breathing exercises? And if you're finding it hard to eat, can you try to make mealtime more enjoyable by cooking something you love or eating with a friend? By breaking down these tasks into smaller, more manageable parts, you may find that they become less overwhelming and more achievable.
column8: Of course, I'm here to help you explore these ideas and find ways to manage your current challenges. It's great that you're recognizing the importance of seeking support and finding ways to make your daily tasks more manageable. By looking into school counseling or tutoring resources, you may be able to better manage your workload and reduce your stress levels. Implementing a more structured schedule can also help you stay on track and make it easier to get out of bed in the morning. Additionally, engaging in daily physical activities can help boost your energy levels and improve your overall well-being. And, as you mentioned, consulting with a doctor can help identify any potential physical health concerns that may be contributing to your exhaustion. Remember, taking care of yourself is crucial, and it's okay to ask for help when you need it. Let's work together to find a solution that works for you.

column3: last week i went in for a job interview that i thought went very well but then i didnt get the job And I think ill never be able to find a good job
column4: Last week, I went in for a job interview that I thought went really well. I felt confident and prepared, and I left the interview feeling positive about my chances. However, to my disappointment, I didn't get the job. It's been weighing on my mind and I can't help but feel like I'll never be able to find a good job.
column5: While it's true that the job interview last week didn't result in a job offer, it doesn't mean that I'll never be able to find a good job. It could be that the job wasn't a great fit, or simply that there was a large pool of candidates and someone else edged me out. Each failed interview is an opportunity to learn and grow, refining my approach for the next application and interview. In addition, there are numerous jobs out there and this particular one is not the only option. I should continue applying and interviewing for other positions, enhancing my skills and qualifications in the process, and not limit myself to thinking one unsuccessful attempt prevents me from future job prospects.
column6: It's understandable to feel disappointed and frustrated after not getting the job you wanted, but it's important to separate this situation from your overall self-worth and future job prospects. Remember that one job interview does not define your entire job search or your potential for success in the future. There are many factors that can influence the outcome of a job interview, and it's possible that the position you applied for was highly competitive or that the hiring manager had different qualifications in mind. Try to focus on the things that went well during the interview and the skills you demonstrated, rather than dwelling on the outcome. By focusing on the positive aspects of the experience, you can build confidence and motivation for future job searches.
column7: It's understandable to feel disappointed and frustrated after a job interview that didn't lead to a job offer, especially when you felt confident and prepared. However, it's important to remember that one job interview does not define your worth or your future job prospects. There are many factors that can influence the hiring process, and sometimes the best candidate doesn't always get the job. Instead of dwelling on the negative thoughts of "I'll never be able to find a good job," let's brainstorm some other possibilities. What are some other job opportunities that you're interested in? Are there any other skills or experiences that you could highlight in your job search? By focusing on these positive aspects, we can work together to help you move forward and find a job that's a good fit for you.
column8:
Of course, I'm here to help you process your thoughts and feelings. It's completely normal to feel disappointed and frustrated after a job interview that didn't result in a job offer, but it's important to recognize that this one setback doesn't define your job search or your future career prospects. You've brainstormed some valuable insights, and I would like to build on those.
Firstly, it's important to acknowledge that rejection is a normal part of the job search process. Many qualified candidates face rejection before landing their dream job, and it doesn't mean that you're not good enough. It could be that the job you interviewed for wasn't the right fit, or that there were other factors at play.
Secondly, you're right that each failed interview is an opportunity to learn and grow. By reflecting on your performance and identifying areas for improvement, you can enhance your skills and qualifications for future interviews. This is a great way to turn a negative experience into a positive one.
Lastly, it's important to keep things in perspective and not limit yourself to one job opportunity. There are numerous jobs out there, and it's important to keep an open mind and continue applying and interviewing for positions that align with your skills and interests.
Remember, you're not alone in this process, and I'm here to support you every step of the way. Keep pushing forward, and don't give up on your job search goals. You got this!

column2: labeling,disqualifying the positive,negative feeling or emotion
column3: my neighbors downstairs were having a party, and would not be quiet so i had to call the police and not get any sleep before work And I think I am being disrespected
column4: I had a really frustrating night last night. My neighbors downstairs were having a party and they were so loud that I couldn't sleep at all. I had to call the police to intervene and it was just a really unpleasant situation. I can't help but feel like they were disrespecting me by being so inconsiderate.
column5: While it's possible my neighbors were being disrespectful by having a loud party, they might have also been unaware of how much their noise was impacting me. Maybe they're new to apartment living and don't understand how sound travels. Instead of immediately assuming disrespect, I could try having a polite conversation with them about the noise and explain how it's affecting my sleep. I could also buy noise-cancelling headphones or earplugs to lessen the noise disruption when I need to sleep. I could also look at it from a lighter perspective; perhaps they were celebrating a significant event and it may not happen frequently. Lastly, understanding that there might be times where my own activities may disturb them, opening a line of communication might lead to mutual respect.
column6: It's understandable that you're feeling frustrated and disrespected by your neighbors' behavior last night. However, try to separate the situation from your thoughts and emotions. It's important to recognize that their actions were not a reflection of your worth or value as a person. You have the right to your own privacy and quiet enjoyment of your home, but it's important to approach the situation in a calm and respectful manner. Instead of dwelling on the negative feelings, try to focus on finding a solution to the problem. Perhaps you could speak with your neighbors and explain how their noise is affecting you, or you could consider using earplugs or white noise to help you sleep. Remember, you don't have to let this situation define your emotional state. You have the power to manage your emotions and find a resolution.
column7: I understand that you're feeling frustrated and disrespected by your neighbors' behavior last night. It's understandable that you want to be able to sleep peacefully in your own home. However, instead of dwelling on the negative thoughts of them being inconsiderate, let's try to brainstorm some other possibilities for how you could handle this situation. For example, you could try talking to your neighbors and explaining how their noise is affecting you. They may not be aware of the disturbance they're causing and may be willing to work with you to find a solution. Alternatively, you could consider using earplugs or white noise machines to help block out the noise. By focusing on these alternative solutions, you may find that you're able to manage your frustration and find a more constructive way to deal with the situation.
column8:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It sounds like you're doing a great job of brainstorming ways to approach the situation with your neighbors. By considering their perspective and potential reasons for the noise, you're showing empathy and a willingness to find a resolution that works for everyone.
I think it's important to remember that communication is key in situations like this. By talking to your neighbors in a polite and respectful manner, you may be able to find a solution that works for both of you. It's possible that they didn't realize how much noise they were making, or that they may be willing to take steps to reduce the noise in the future.
Additionally, as you mentioned, there may be times when your own activities could be disturbing them, and by opening up a line of communication, you can work together to find a mutually respectful solution.
Remember, it's important to approach the situation with empathy and understanding, rather than jumping to conclusions or assumptions about your neighbors' intentions. By doing so, you may be able to find a resolution that works for everyone involved.

column3: one of my friend posted a video of a spider getting inside a car, and she so happened to have had her car broken into. So i asked her if the police found whoever broke into her car, and she totally ignored me And I think maybe she doesn't like me anymore.
column4: I feel hurt and confused by my friend's response to my question about her car being broken into. It seems like she ignored me, and I can't help but wonder if she doesn't like me anymore.
column5: Maybe she missed my message as she might be dealing with a lot due to the incident and getting her car fixed. Or perhaps she felt uncomfortable discussing the car incident as it could still be a fresh traumatic experience. Another possibility could be that she's too busy dealing with the insurance and the police, so she overlooked my message. In another perspective, she might have thought that my comment trivialized her traumatic experience. Alternatively, she may not have noticed my question about the break-in as it got lost in all the other comments about the spider video.
column6: It's understandable that you feel hurt and confused by your friend's response, but it's important to separate the situation from your thought about it. Just because your friend didn't respond immediately or in the way you wanted doesn't necessarily mean she doesn't like you. It's possible that she was busy or preoccupied with other things, or that she didn't realize the impact of her response on you. Try to focus on the facts of the situation rather than jumping to conclusions about your friend's feelings. Remember, people can have different communication styles and ways of processing information, and it's important to be understanding and patient with each other.
column7: It's understandable that you feel hurt and confused by your friend's response, and it's natural to wonder if she might not like you anymore. However, it's important to remember that people often respond in ways that are not necessarily a reflection of their feelings towards us. Perhaps your friend was busy or preoccupied when you asked about her car, or maybe she didn't want to burden you with the details of her situation. Instead of jumping to conclusions, try asking her directly and openly about how she's doing and if there's anything she wants to talk about. By doing so, you can clear the air and give her the opportunity to share her thoughts and feelings with you.
column8:
Of course, I understand. It can be difficult to navigate situations where we feel misunderstood or ignored, especially when it comes to something as personal as a traumatic experience. It's important to remember that everyone processes and responds to situations differently, and it's possible that your friend may have been dealing with her own emotions and responsibilities that prevented her from immediately responding to your message.
Rather than jumping to conclusions or assuming the worst, it might be helpful to reach out to your friend directly and express your concerns in a non-accusatory way. You could say something like, "Hey, I noticed you didn't respond to my message about your car being broken into. Is everything okay? I just wanted to check in and make sure you're doing alright." This can help clear the air and give your friend the opportunity to share their perspective and feelings with you.
Remember, communication is key in any relationship, and being open and empathetic can go a long way in building trust and understanding.
